title: Machine Learning Integrated Robotics for Learning Physical Artistry
description:
One of the main reasons I worked at FAR-Labs in NYC was to pursue my personal research on augmenting the physical artist’s workflow. I focused on using the ShadeSketch ML model and the AxiDraw to detect line drawings and programmatically draw realistic shading on them from a given light direction. Shadowing can be challenging for novice physical artists, but once they have a robotic pen plotter shade for them, they begin to understand its intricacies.

Furthermore, with the robotic shading pipeline complete, I hope to run a user case study on the outcomes of this unique human-robotics interaction. Specifically, I will study how artists react to the robot’s shading capabilities and how that implies conclusions on future human-robotics interactions.

title: Custom Audio Machine Learning for Robotic Design
description:
One of my advisors, David Goedicke, does extensive research on how audio can be used to improve human-robotics interactions through machine learning. I spent a large portion of a summer programming with him to create a streamlined system that allows anyone to upload their own audio ML models and use them to control a small robot.

Through node-red, Google's Teachable Machines, and some backend development, we provided a simple process for building robots that naturally react to sounds in ways not possible to the average, non-technical person.

Links to both custom node-red nodes can be found on my GitHub.

title: Cross Cultural Driving Simulator
description:
Autonomous vehicles have issues dealing with ambiguous driving scenarios, such as when two or more cars arrive at a four way intersection at the same time. These ambiguities grow when self-driving cars are placed in other countries with unique traffic laws and driver behaviors.

So, I've been working with FAR-Labs on their virtual reality driving simulator, which is meant to collect data on these scenarios. Specifically, I've been running New York City studies and writing detailed documentation for future users.

title: Grow Crazy!
description:
After countless long work hours with my team, Sprout Studios, our game "Grow Crazy!" was released on May 21st, 2022. In it, you play a housekeeper frantically trying to keep a mansion tidy while a mischievous plant tries to knock expensive artifacts off shelves!

The game contains full co-op support, over 20 levels, and a unique gameplay experience against an AI controlled plant. On the 22nd, we presented "Grow Crazy!" at the end-of-year game exposition, where 500 attendees had the opportunity to play.

title: CUSD Ithaca Carbon Neutral 2030 Modeling
description:
Cornell University Sustainable Design (CUSD) is a project team focused on creating a more sustainable future. I work on this team as a Computer Science lead for the subteam, ICN 2030 Modeling.

The Ithaca Carbon Neutral 2030 Modeling team, among other things, was focused on implementing a data generator that could provide training data for our central ML model. We wrote software using RhinoCommon, a C# library used to create plugins for the modeling software Rhino, that can generate a building model file with given dimensions.

I've also written a basic React website to house our ML model for distribution to Ithacan residents as to help reduce carbon emissions. Below is a link to the in progress React site and the team's final report for more information.

title: Immersive Bus Ride
description:
The Immsersive Bus Ride is an in progress Roosevelt Island Tour project where guests are accompanied with Oculus Quest headsets and are driven around the island learning about climate change. During this project, I maintained and setup technical equipment and assisted with software problems as necessary.

As climate change is one of humanity's most pressing problems, the public needs to be come more informed on effective measures to take. So, through the immersive VR bus ride, guests experience a different future of Roosevelt Island.

I'm currently working with other peers to write a publication to be released.

title: CUHousing
description:
During the Spring semester of 2022, I took Cornell Design Tech Initiative's course, Trends in Web Developemnt. In this course, we learned the basics of React web development with TypeScript, culminating in a final project with a team of 4.

We decided to create CUHousing, a Cornell University tool that allows students to quickly overview information on avaliable housing options on and off campus.

title: Critter World Simulation
description:
During my first semester at Cornell University, I dived into the course entitled "CS2112 Honors Object-Oriented Design and Data Structures". For the final project of this course, split up into multiple assignments, we were tasked to simulate a world of critters, complete with a GUI, parser for an abstract syntax tree, and more!

The software simulates "critters" in a user or randomly generated world through the following supported actions: breeding, attacking, eating, dying, moving, and custom critter reactions. A pdf of the assignment description can be found below.
